results.title: The China teapot story: a Chinese legend
results.creator_credit: Wladislaw Neherbecki and Sterling Educational Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Folktales from around the world”.
An animated story about a Chinese potter who makes a beautiful porcelain teapot for the Emperor who regards its worth as priceless. It is then seen to be desirable and is inevitably stolen from the Emperor’s palace. In a series of transactions that follow in various parts of the world, it is exchanged for items from other cultures that are equally regarded as priceless. Provides a simple introduction to the notion of trade, as well as the economic and aesthetic considerations involved in the determination of the worth of a product. Suitable for middle and upper primary level.

results.title: The Children of the mist
results.creator_credit: Conon Fraser, David H. Fowler and New Zealand National Film Unit
results.brief_description: Describes some of the problems of adjustment that the Maori and Polynesian islanders have, as they try to integrate into the European society of New Zealand, but still retain their tribal identity.

results.title: The Children of the city
results.creator_credit: Budge Cooper, Paul Rotha and Paul Rotha Productions
results.brief_description: This film illustrates how the Scottish Courts, under a recent Act of Parliament, treat the problems of juvenile delinquency, through the work of probation officers, child guidance clinics, and approved schools.

results.title: The Children of Bet Alpha
results.creator_credit: Krosney, Phoenix Films and Ritzau Film
results.brief_description: An intensive look at Israel’s communal approach to raising children, shot at Kibbutz Bet Alpha. Looks at four age groups within Bet Alpha - infants, three year olds, seven year olds and twelve year olds. The camera records the children’s behaviour and the film describes in detail Bet Alpha’s approach to collective education which in many ways preceded other modern approaches to education.

results.title: The Children must learn
results.creator_credit: Willard Van Dyke, Documentary Film Productions and Educational Film Institute of New York University
results.brief_description: Designed to illustrate the unsatisfactory relationship between education and the local necessities of life which characterises education in many parts of the USA. The film presents a study of farm families in the poorer mountain communities of the rural south, inadequately housed and clothed, ill-fed, living onland which yearly returns them less and less. One of the first tasks of education is to ensure that the children’s school curriculum meets the needs of their daily life.

results.title: The Children's physical education display on the Melbourne Cricket Ground
results.creator_credit: State Film Centre of Victoria and Victoria. Visual Education Centre
results.brief_description: The display of seven spectacular items, presented by 17,000 children aged 7 to 17, at the Melbourne Cricket Ground on March 4, 1954, in honour of Queen Elizabeth and the Duke of Edinburgh, in front of a crowd of 92,000. Items arranged and directed by the Physical Education Branch. Music by RAAF Central Band.

results.title: The Children's fountain
results.creator_credit: George Zabriskie, U.S. Committee for UNICEF and United Nations
results.brief_description: Shows the programs of the Turkish Government to improve the health and welfare of their children. These programs are aided by UNICEF and other UN agencies. They are seen through the eyes of a young nurse, who takes additional special training and becomes part of a pilot project for rural nursing.

results.title: The Children
results.creator_credit: Department of Public Information of the United Nations
results.brief_description: This film describes the work of the United Nations International Children’s Emergency Fund. It shows how the drive for increased food production, the health programs and the educational activities of UNICEF are being carried out in many areas to provide a more hopeful world for tomorrow’s citizens.

results.title: The Child watchers
results.creator_credit: Jean Oser, L. Richard Ellison, National Educational Television and Time-Life Broadcast
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The World We Live In”.
The reflexes of a newborn baby are the basis for early learning, this is shown to be more extensive than was once thought. Experiments by developmental psychologists such as Piaget and Brunner are demonstrated with children up to the age of 6. Based on the book “The Mind” by John Rowan Wilson - a volume in the Life Science Library. Narrated by Luis Van Rooten. Suggested audience: senior secondary, tertiary, general.

results.title: The Chaparral prince
results.creator_credit: Mark Cullingham, Elaine Sperber and Highgate Pictures
results.brief_description: Based on a short story by O Henry, it tells the story of frail young Lena, who is hired out by her father to a wicked innkeeper. Lena finds escape in a book of fairy tales about handsome princes who save maidens in distress. When the innkeeper throws the book on the fire, a chain of events is started which proves to Lena that fairy tales can come true. Suitable for middle and upper primary levels.
